advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (JAN. 1980)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Right now, your computer for today"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"The computing answer"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>November 1987<br><br><font color="#666666"> ...This elegant little machine takes family computing into new dimensions of creativity, excitement and productivity. It outruns and outguns office PCs as a business multi-tasker, performing a deskful of different jobs simultaneously at over 7 million steps per second in realtime... </font> </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> T-3100 (FEB. 1987)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert says:<br><br><font color="#666666"> Until now, working away from your office meant baving to settle for lesser computers or no computer at all.<br> Toshiba ends that compromise. The T3100 delivers the power of an IBM PC AT in a lean, 15-pound computer that you can take with you. With a full-sized keyboard and advanced gas plasma display that give you equal comfort and clarity on your desk or on the road <br><br> Don't let its size fool you.<br> Though the T3100 is no bigger than many laptop computers, it offers the power of a full function IBM compatible desktop AT system. You get the speed and ease of a built-in hard disk, communications and expansion options, and more-including dual-voltage power that lets you plug in and go to work just about anywhere in the world.</font> </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> COMPUTER TERMINAL TO NETWORK STATION</strong></font><br><blockquote>The HiNet local network system allowed data to be transfered at a 256 Kbyte/sec. speed. It was able to run under CP/M or MS/DOS operating systems. </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> KIT VERSION (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> LOGABAX STICKER</strong></font><br><blockquote>"What a quantum leap, Logabax!"<br> "I would say even more, what a quantum leap!"<p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b>http://tintinomanie.chez.tiscali.fr/</b> © Moulinsart</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> DISK DRIVE #2 FEB. 1983</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert says:<br><br><font color="#666666"> These 35-track, 51/4" double-density drives will give you the high-level performance you want from your Color Computer. Each drive puts over 156K of on-line data and program storage right at your fingertips. And you can chain up to four drives together for a total of more than 626K. <br><br> Yet all that extra storage is available at a seek time of 30 milliseconds and a data transfer rate of 250 bits per second...</font></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (1984)</strong></font><br><blockquote>This is an advert from the ILLEL store</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN LEAFLET #3</strong></font><br><blockquote>"There music puts in it"<p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b>www.sharpmz.org</b> </p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (SEPT. 1987)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Arcades games in an armchair"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH BROCHURE #4</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Jacques Sorro</b></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> TEI BROCHURE COVER</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (DEC.1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Micro price, Mega features"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> AMIGAWORLD PREVIEW</strong></font><br><blockquote>Thanks to Jun Suzuki <a href="http://member.nifty.ne.jp/tarucus/museum/cool/cool.htm">web site</a></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE ADVERT #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>This is an advertisement for the HX-10D. If you can read japanese maybe you could tell us what's the difference with a HX-10...</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT.</strong></font><br><blockquote>This advert was for the Serie 5 and the ACS-8000 systems.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.K. AD (APR. 86)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> RUSSIAN ADVERT - PAGE 2</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to Taras Ponomarev for this advert</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMOTIONAL PICTURE</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">thanks to datareign.co.uk for this picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> BROCHURE #5</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROUD !</strong></font><br><blockquote>This authentic picture show a proud owner of a Wren transportable computer ! It looks like it bought it 5 minutes ago as he doesn't really know from which side to handle it...</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (APRIL 1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

computer.coprocessor: Video chip must be compatible with the Texas Instruments TMS 9918/A or TMS 9928/A (Japan : 60 Hz) or TMS 9929/A (Europe : 50 Hz)
computer.description:
This is apparently a classic MSX 1 computer, though this particular model is quite rare!
Its particularity is to have three cartridge slots!

emulator.description: A Bresilian MSX Emulator written in 100% assembler
emulator.name: BrMSX

emulator.description: A MSX Emulator for Win95 and Win NT + Direct X
emulator.name: RuMSX

emulator.description: fMSX is a portable MSX emulator ported on : Amiga OS, Mac OS, MS DOS, OS/2, Sony Playstation, Risc OS, Towns OS, Unix / X, Win95 / NT, X68K.
emulator.name: fMSX official Homepage

emulator.description: This new MSX emulator can reproduce, among many other MSX, MSX2and MSX2+ machines, both Panasonic Turbo-R models. Be sure to get the catapult frontend and the system roms from FUNET.
emulator.name: openMSX - The MSX emulator that aims for perfection.

computer.graphics: Mode 2 : 256 x 192 with 16 colors (Hires mode)Mode 3 : 64 x 48 with 16 colors (Multi colour mode)32 sprites

item.description: National CF-2131|||16 KB RAM expansion|||<br><font color="red"><strong>> NATIONAL CF-2131</strong></font><br><strong>> 16 KB RAM expansion</strong><br><blockquote></blockquote>
Casio OR-216 - 16 KB RAM expansion|||Box|||<br><font color="red"><strong>> CASIO OR-216 - 16 KB RAM EXPANSION</strong></font><br><strong>> Box</strong><br><blockquote></blockquote>

Philips RAM expansion||||||<br><font color="red"><strong>> PHILIPS RAM EXPANSION</strong></font><br><blockquote>RAM expansion and LOGO language cartridges.<p class="petitgris">Thanks to Daniele from Italy</p></blockquote>

MEGA RAM DISK 256|||from DDX (Brazil)|||<br><font color="red"><strong>> MEGA RAM DISK 256</strong></font><br><strong>> from DDX (Brazil)</strong><br><blockquote>This is the famous Megaram cartridge made in Brzail, used to play all Konami cracked Megarom games.6401999243</blockquote>

Panasonic FS-IFA1 & FW-RSU1W|||Scanner/Printer interface|||<br><font color="red"><strong>> PANASONIC FS-IFA1 & FW-RSU1W</strong></font><br><strong>> Scanner/Printer interface</strong><br><blockquote>The FS-IFA1 is the printer/scanner interface (left on the picture) and the FW-RSU1W is the handheld scanner (right on the picture). These expansions are for MSX2 systems.</blockquote>
Sony HBI-232|||RS232c cartridge|||<br><font color="red"><strong>> SONY HBI-232</strong></font><br><strong>> RS232c cartridge</strong><br><blockquote>Used to connect serial printers.</blockquote>

Yamaha mouse #1||||||<br><font color="red"><strong>> YAMAHA MOUSE #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>This mouse was compatible with all MSX systems. It connects to the first Joystick port.<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>www.zonadepruebas.com</b></p></blockquote>
Yamaha mouse #2||||||<br><font color="red"><strong>> YAMAHA MOUSE #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>Brand new!<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>www.zonadepruebas.com</b></p></blockquote>

Philips VW0020|||80-col dot-matrix printer|||<br><font color="red"><strong>> PHILIPS VW0020</strong></font><br><strong>> 80-col dot-matrix printer</strong><br><blockquote>This printer was a rebadged version of the Seikosha GP-500.<br> It was a 80-column, 50 CPS model with a 7x5 dot matrix head.<br> Commodore and Atari used same hardware basis for their MPS-801 and 1029 printers. </blockquote>

Sanyo DR-202||||||<br><font color="red"><strong>> SANYO DR-202</strong></font><br><blockquote>The ADSS system allowed to quickly search a specific program in a cassette tape and load it. Seach time for a C60 cassette was less than 1 minute.</blockquote>

Bit-corder||||||<br><font color="red"><strong>> BIT-CORDER</strong></font><br><blockquote>Cassete recorder dedicated to Hit-Bit MSX systems, though it could be used with any home computers.</blockquote>

computer.keyboard: Full-stroke keyboard, including 5 F-keys with 10 functions and 4 arrow keys
computer.name: Wavy 3
computer.ports: Joystick socket (1 or 2)3 cardridge slotsTape-recorder plug (1200/2400 bauds)RGB video outputCentronics interface
computer.ram: At least 8kB (most machines had 64kB built in)
computer.sound: General Instruments AY-3-8910 Programmable Sound Generator3 channels, 8 octaves
